content: t was meant to be a harmless selfie, designed to highlight the plight of the endangered crested black macaque.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: But British photographer David Slater, who is at the centre of a bizarre court battle of the now

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p a span
html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: , has revealed that being sued by a monkey has ruined his life and left him completely broke.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: The 52-year-old from south Wales, who specialises in wildlife and conservation photography, said he has been left penniless after

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p a span
html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: over whether he or the macaque owns the copyright of the picture.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: Mr Slater, who couldn't even afford a flight to America to be at the court hearing on Thursday, said that he is considering giving up his career as a photographer, and becoming a tennis coach or a dog-walker instead.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: “This would be a new venture for me. It would pay peanuts, but at least it would be more than photography,” Mr Slater told The Telegraph.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: “I am just not motivated to go out and take photos any more. I’ve had outlays of several thousand pounds for lawyers, it is losing me income and getting me so depressed. When I think about the whole situation I really don’t think it’s worth it.”

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: lthough his photograph of a grinning monkey is famous across the globe, Mr Slater says his income is around £100 every few months from image sales.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: “Everything I did to try and highlight the plight of the monkeys has backfired on my private life,” Mr Slater said. “I’ve had my life ruined”.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div div div div q span
content: Everything I did to try and highlight the plight of the monkeys has backfired on my private life

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div div div div span

content: r Slater travelled to Sulawesi, Indonesia, and spent a week taking pictures of macaques in 2011. He said he mounted the camera on his tripod, and then gradually persuaded the monkeys to press the shutter while looking into the lens.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: In 2014 he asked Wikipedia to take down his picture after they published it without his permission, but the web giant refused and said that the copyright belonged to the monkey.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: The US Copyright Office ruled that animals cannot own copyright but People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) sued Mr Slater in 2015.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div div div div div div div div span
content: Monkey selfie photographer enters legal battle with PETA

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div div div div div div a span
html body div div main div div article div div div p span
html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: t a court hearing on Thursday in front of a federal appeal judge at the 9th Circuit in San Francisco, lawyers for Mr Slater said it was “absurd” for Peta to claim that the monkey was entitled to copyright on behalf of a monkey.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: Angela Dunning, representing Mr Slater, told the court that PETA was “not even sure they have the right monkey”, referring to Naruto. “It is absurd to say a monkey can sue for copyright infringement. Naruto can’t benefit financially from his work. He is a monkey.”

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: ndrew Dhuey, also representing Mr Slater, said PETA should pay all of his legal fees because “monkey see, monkey sue will not do in federal court”.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: Judge Carlos Bea asked why the case should not be dismissed and asked if anyone could point to the law which said "man and monkey are the same".

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: Judge N. Randy Smith said: "There's no loss as to reputation. There's no even allegation that the copyright could have benefitted somehow Naruto. What financial benefits apply to him? There’s nothing".

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div figure figcaption span
content: The photograph of a grinning monkey is famous across the globe

content: n spite of everything, Mr Slater said he does not regret taking the picture of the monkey. On the contrary, he said he is “absolutely delighted”.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: “It has taken six years for my original intention to come true which was to highlight the plight of the monkeys and bring it to the world,” he said.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: “No one had heard of these monkeys six years ago, they were down to the last thousands.”

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: He said that thanks to the publicity that his “monkey selfie” attracted, impoverished locals no longer shoot or eat macaques because “The locals used to roast them, but now they love them, they call it the ‘selfie monkey’,” he said.

tag: html body div div main div div article div div div p span
content: “Tourists are now visiting and people see there is a longer-term benefit to the community than just shooting a monkey.”
